awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Political Stability in the Era of Global Capitalism
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to explain how political stability in the developing world in the age of global capitalism is achieved. Recent Turkish political history provides a unique case to test and extend theories on this issue. Between 1989 and 2002, Turkey witnessed 11 consecutive governments. This tumultuous period ended only when the economic crises of 2000/2001 altered power relations, resulting in unpopular reforms that led to the election of the Justice and Development Party. The JDP has maintained its political hegemony since then, winning consecutive landslide victories over the last 13 years. Why were the short-lived governments of Turkey's lost decade of the 1990s unable to prevent the breakup of their respective regimes? How was it possible for the current JDP to maintain its rule since 2002? This research hypothesizes that: (1) The dynamics between the banking sector and the public debt regime systematically generated conflicts among the ruling elite, inhibiting political parties from forming viable coalitions during the 1990s, and that (2) the successful resolutions of these conflicts after the 2001 economic crisis account for the JDP's ability to bring about stability. With a focus on finance and state-capital relations, I  seek to explore an overlooked, but potentially significant, factor shaping political arrangements.

This project employs a qualitative research methodology, based on a detailed within-case comparative historical-sociological analysis. The project uses two research strategies that are widely used by sociologists: an extensive historical investigation of archived materials produced by selected state institutions and private organizations, and semi-structured in-depth interviews with political and economic elites in Turkey. Combining these two primary sources, I aim not only to understand micro-level dynamics of political stability by scrutinizing incentives behind how elites reach (or fail to reach) consensus under given economic constraints and political pressures, but also to discover larger structural and institutional forces underlying political decision-making processes at the state level. Therefore, this research will produce reproducible, generalizable and falsifiable results since the findings and claims can be tested against ?matching? (positive or negative) historically situated and/or counter-factual cases. The project's analysis of how finance shapes electoral politics and governing institutions can potentially offer generalizable policy suggestions concerning developmental issues and democratic governance practices.

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to explain how political stability in the developing world in the age of global capitalism is achieved and maintained. Recent Turkish political history provides a unique case to test and extend theories on this issue. Between 1989 and 2002, Turkey witnessed 11 consecutive governments, mostly either in the form of multi-party coalitions or caretaker minority governments. What abruptly closed this chapter of the country’s recent political history were the 2002 elections, as the semi-religious Justice and Development Party [JDP] formed a single-party majority government. The JDP could since then successfully establish its hegemony, winning consecutive landslide victories in every election it entered. Despite facing recent challenges to its power -such as the Gezi movement and the corruption scandals in 2013, Syrian crisis on the country's border, failed coup attempt in 2016, etc.-, the governing party has been able to survive to this day. Moreover, with the passing of the April 2017 Constitutional Referendum, JDP has achieved to replace Turkey's long-standing parliamentary regime with a presidential system; and its leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is inaugurated as the first president of this new regime, in June 2018.

This puzzle requires one to engage with both faces of the problem; namely, political instability in the 1990s, and stability that came with the JDP’s rise to power in the 2000s (which has increasingly been eroded in recent years). Although it scrutinizes a single case, Turkey, this project is essentially comparative in its design, since from a theoretical perspective, it attempts to examine not one but two different countries: there were two different sets of historically-conditional causal mechanisms at work that produced two divergent path-dependent political outcomes for the country in the period that we study. Most conventional accounts explain the JDP’s success by recourse to the rise of religious ideologies and the party’s ability to reconcile Islam and democracy. Although this perspective may explain why people choose to vote for the party in elections, it is virtually silent on how the JDP governments could constrain its intra-party conflicts to a sufficient minimum; and impose coherence at the level of its cabinet and state bureaucracy during its era of power, thus political stability.

Our primary theoretical insight—the arrow of causality running from the economic to the political— not only promises a novel explanation to this puzzle, but it also sheds new light to the existing body of political sociological literature on state theories in general, and reform processes in particular, by analyzing and empirically showing the impact of the interplay between capital accumulation dynamics, institutional settings and ruling elites on political deadlocks and their resolutions in the global capitalist context of state policies. Relying on three years of fieldwork, including an extensive investigation of economic data and archived materials produced by selected state institutions and private organizations, semi-structured in-depth interviews with political and economic elites in Turkey, an exhaustive survey on newspaper sources, as well as a theoretically-inspired, critical engagement with secondary literature, we seek to show that an analysis of political stability should be understood as inter-related to, yet distinct from, an analysis of party hegemony.

In a nutshell, this project argues that financial instability created political instability in Turkey’s long-decade of 1990s. Contrary to most mainstream accounts that link lax regulation of the banking sector with irresponsible/corrupt politicians and inadequate institutional setting, we argue that lax regulation of the banking sector was not only urged by the Turkish state’s commitment to deepen financial markets, it was also desired by the most powerful fraction of the Turkish ruling economic elites, namely, the business groups that controlled the banking sector. Yet, interrelated dynamics between de-regulated banking sector and public debt management systematically generated contradictions among the ruling elites, bringing about economic and/or political crises. These crises, as a result, led to the erosion of the legitimacy of incumbent governments, which found it increasingly difficult to form viable coalitions. This period ended only when the economic crises of 2000/2001 resulted in reforms that altered power relations but were unpopular, leading to the election of the JDP. In short, it was the realignment of power relations in accordance with the changing incentive structures of the ruling factions of the political and economic elites alongside with the expansionary patterns in financial flows at the global scale, as well as JDP's commitment to embrace regulatory reforms previous government passed, that brought about political stability in Turkey. What the JDP accomplished, on the other hand, was to successfully build social consensus around its rule, hence establishing its political hegemony.

The project’s analysis of how national and global financial crises shape electoral politics and governing institutions in Turkey can potentially offer insights and policy suggestions concerning developmental issues and democratic governance practices elsewhere, as its findings may prove to be reproducible and generalizable to other similar cases.
